content.body: fwiw I've been calling the opposite of 'light dismiss' 'explicit dismiss' , might be another word we could opt for as the opposite of light close / dismiss
"Everything is a lot." — annevk
Hidde de Vries: I would not mind `implicitclose`, I don't think we want "dismiss" as a novel term as it won't be immediately recognizable as "close" to all people
content.formatted_body: Hidde de Vries: I would not mind implicitclose, I don't think we want "dismiss" as a novel term as it won't be immediately recognizable as "close" to all people

content.body: Hidde de Vries: although `lightclose` and `softclose` seem easier to spell, which is another consideration
content.formatted_body: Hidde de Vries: although lightclose and softclose seem easier to spell, which is another consideration

Hmmmm, if we want to have an attribute that always outputs a particular interface type from the getter, but wants to *accept* a dictionary type for the setter, is that at all possible?
content.formatted_body: Hmmmm, if we want to have an attribute that always outputs a particular interface type from the getter, but wants to accept a dictionary type for the setter, is that at all possible?

content.body: It looks like the answer is no, dictionary types aren't allowed in an attribute type, since the implication is that the attribute type is both the getter output and the setter input (and you can't use dictionaries in output types)
(I suspect the answer is that, right now, it's required to type the attribute as `any` and handle the conversions by hand.)
content.formatted_body: (I suspect the answer is that, right now, it's required to type the attribute as any and handle the conversions by hand.)

content.body: TabAtkins: IDL has an open issue to split getters and setters (plus maybe have convenient syntax for when they're the same); we should still do that
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: IDL has an open issue to split getters and setters (plus maybe have convenient syntax for when they're the same); we should still do that

content.body: ah, cool. so "no, but later yes"
hai
zcorpan: https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9301#issuecomment-1719284356
TIL `document.open(); document.close()` is a "turn off mutation events" flag in Chrome/Safari.
content.formatted_body: TIL document.open(); document.close() is a "turn off mutation events" flag in Chrome/Safari.

content.body: That is interesting. I wonder what is the historical reason for that.
The specification requires flipping it on and then off. And maybe they just forgot to turn it on again?
I think the specification is more recent though
Ah, no, that part was untouched in the rewrite https://html.spec.whatwg.org/commit-snapshots/c9e804f04d03a0658bfa689cb0f368a4d2e37936/?C=M&O=A#dom-document-open
Firefox doesn't quite follow the spec either, it turns them off until `document.close()` turns them back on, instead of the spec which requires turning them off just for the removal step.
content.formatted_body: Firefox doesn't quite follow the spec either, it turns them off until document.close() turns them back on, instead of the spec which requires turning them off just for the removal step.

content.body: (or in the new spec, the "replace all" step)
how did you test that? Note, all the events listeners are supposed to be removed

ah, it is  a bit different. Listeners added after document.open() are called, if one modifies the DOM using normal methods, but .write() itself doesn't seem to notify DOM side, so no events are fired with .write().
